node.title: How Does This End?
node.alt: Cable car riders in San Francisco.
node.content: ["Among the Covid experts I regularly talk with, Dr. Robert Wachter is one of the more cautious. He worries about \u201clong Covid,\u201d and he believes that many people should receive booster shots. He says that he may wear a mask in supermarkets and on airplanes for the rest of his life.", "Yet Wachter \u2014 the chair of the medicine department at the University of California, San Francisco \u2014 also worries about the downsides of organizing our lives around Covid. In recent weeks, he has begun to think about when most of life\u2019s rhythms should start returning to normal. Increasingly, he believes the answer is: Now.", "This belief stems from the fact that the virus is unlikely to go away, ever. Like most viruses, it will probably keep circulating, with cases rising sometimes and falling other times. But we have the tools \u2014 vaccines, along with an emerging group of treatments \u2014 to turn it into a manageable virus, similar to the seasonal flu.", "Given this reality, Wachter, who\u2019s 64, has decided to resume more of his old activities and accept the additional risk that comes with them, much as we accept the risk of crashes when riding in vehicles.", "He has begun eating in indoor restaurants again and playing poker, unmasked, with vaccinated friends. He has taken airplanes to visit relatives. He hosted a medical conference in downtown San Francisco with a few hundred masked and vaccinated attendees.", "\u201cI\u2019m still going to be thoughtful and careful,\u201d Wachter told The San Francisco Chronicle. But \u201cif I\u2019m not going to do it now, I\u2019m probably saying that I\u2019m not going to do it for the next couple of years, and I might be saying I\u2019m not doing it forever.\u201d", "The hospitalization statistics in highly vaccinated communities help explain Wachter\u2019s attitude. In Seattle (which publishes detailed data), the daily Covid hospitalization rate for vaccinated people has been slightly above one in one million. By comparison, the flu hospitalization rate in a typical year in the U.S. is more than twice as high. For most vaccinated people in a place like Seattle or San Francisco, Covid already resembles just another virus.", "The risks are also low for unvaccinated children because Covid tends to be mild for them. (Plus, any child 5 or older can now be vaccinated.) For young children, Covid looks like a normal flu, if not a mild one:", "As for long Covid, it is real but rare. It\u2019s also not unique. The flu and other viruses also cause mysterious, lasting problems for a small share of people, studies show.", "The bottom line is that Covid now presents the sort of risk to most vaccinated people that we unthinkingly accept in other parts of life. And there is not going to be a day when we wake up to headlines proclaiming that Covid is defeated. In many ways, the future of the virus has arrived.", "All of which raises the question of which precautions should end \u2014 now or soon \u2014 and which should become permanent.", "Should offices remain mostly empty? Should schools require children and teachers to wear masks? Should classrooms go remote again when they identify a new Covid case? (In Boston, a K-8 school closed for 10 days starting Wednesday because of an outbreak.) For how long should individuals organize their own lives around a fear of Covid?", "Most of these questions are tricky, and a few factors can guide the decision-making, epidemiologists say.", "The lower the rate of Covid spread in a community, the less risk to everyone. The C.D.C. defines a low rate of transmission as, among other things, fewer than 10 new daily cases per 100,000 people. Most of the country is well above that threshold, but parts of the San Francisco, Atlanta, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, New York and Washington areas are below it. (You can look up your county here.)", "Nevada has taken an approach that experts like Julia Raifman of Boston University have praised: The state will remove mask mandates after cases have fallen below a certain level. Joseph Allen of Harvard, criticizing the different approach in many other places, has said, \u201cWe\u2019re sleepwalking into policy because we\u2019re not setting goals.\u201d", "One complication: Nationally, new cases have risen modestly in recent weeks, though they are still far below the levels of late summer. If new cases accelerate as the weather gets colder and more activity moves indoors, it may call for caution.", "Still, with vaccines widely available and treatments increasingly so, caseloads are not as important a metric as they once were. They \u201care becoming less and less useful,\u201d as The Atlantic\u2019s Sarah Zhang has written. More telling measures are hospitalizations and deaths.", "The treatments for people who contract Covid are especially important here. Pfizer\u2019s pill regimen, which seems especially effective, reduces the risk of hospitalization by more than 80 percent. These treatments are another step toward turning Covid into a normal virus rather than one that dominates life.", "Different people face different levels of Covid risk. For most vaccinated people and children, the risks are extremely low. But for some immunocompromised people \u2014 like those who have received organ transplants \u2014 the risks are higher. The same is true among people in their 80s and 90s.", "Greater precautions make sense for vulnerable people. They will also particularly benefit if rapid Covid testing ever becomes widely available in the U.S., allowing them to socialize more confidently.", "There is a flip side to this point: The aggregate statistics on Covid deaths and hospitalizations exaggerate the risk to most Americans, because a disproportionate share of severe illness occurs among people with specific medical vulnerabilities.", "Wachter told me that he might always wear a mask while grocery shopping or flying on a plane because the costs of having a covered face and a muzzled voice in those settings are virtually zero. He isn\u2019t usually trying to have a conversation with somebody. And a mask can help protect him from all sorts of respiratory viruses.", "Unfortunately, the costs of most Covid interventions are higher. Masks inhibit communication, especially for young children and the hard of hearing. (Wachter also says he expects conferences eventually to be maskless.) Remote school has been a failure. Remote office work hampers collaboration. Social isolation causes mental-health problems.", "When The Washington Post recently asked Jennifer Nuzzo, an epidemiologist at Johns Hopkins University, when the pandemic would end, she replied: \u201cIt doesn\u2019t end. We just stop caring. Or we care a lot less.\u201d She added, \u201cI think for most people, it just fades into the background of their lives.\u201d", "I realize that answer may sound jarring, but the alternative \u2014 a society permanently dominated by Covid \u2014 is jarring, too. Eventually, the costs of organizing our lives around the virus will exceed the benefits. In some cases, we may have already reached that point.", "A programming note: I\u2019ll be traveling on assignment next week, and my colleagues will be writing The Morning. I\u2019ll be back in your inboxes on Tuesday, Nov. 23.", "Aristotle was right: Imagination is awesome, says David Brooks.", "Trends: \u201cTikTok hair\u201d has ancient roots.", "275 minutes on hold: Why airline customer service still can\u2019t keep up.", "Veterans Day: At 96, the parade came to him.", "Modern Love: The manny diaries.", "Lives Lived: As Barnard College\u2019s first Black full-time faculty member, Quandra Prettyman developed some of the country\u2019s first courses on Black female writers. She died at 88.", "\u201cBefore there was bread or pasta, much less meat or fish, there was rice,\u201d Hanya Yanagihara writes in T magazine. Though rice has origins in both Asia and Africa, it\u2019s hard to find a culture that hasn\u2019t made the foodstuff its own: fried, pur\u00e9ed, roasted, baked, scorched. And so, for T\u2019s winter travel issue, writers explored the world through the grain. Some highlights:", "Senegal, which consumes more rice per capita than almost any other African nation, is attempting to resuscitate homegrown varieties.", "Mansaf, a dish of lamb and rice, is a national symbol in Jordan and a taste of home for suburban Detroit\u2019s Arab American diaspora.", "In Mexico, rice arrived via the Spanish Conquest, making its presence there inextricable from colonialism.", "And when browned on the bottom of a pot, rice becomes a treasure prized by food cultures in Iran, Vietnam, the Philippines and more. \u2014 Sanam Yar, a Morning writer", "Fancy yet fast: gochugaru salmon with toasted rice.", "\u201cPassing,\u201d a piercing drama about two friends navigating the color line in 1920s New York, is a Times critic\u2019s pick.", "Will Smith\u2019s memoir is \u201ca fairy tale of dazzling good fortune,\u201d albeit from an admittedly unreliable narrator, Alexandra Jacobs writes.", "Jimmy Kimmel pondered the sentencing of the QAnon Shaman.", "See how well you followed this week\u2019s headlines, and how you compare with other Times readers.", "The pangram from yesterday\u2019s Spelling Bee was locomotion.
